channel.title: Writing Files To Desktop
channel.description: I am writing a program and I need to send the text file to the desktop. I can do PrintWrite out File, but I'm not sure how to direct the text file to the desktop. Any help? :D

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:40, topic:213296”][quote author=supamagier link=topic=280774.msg2282529#msg2282529 date=1213758046]
just use C:\Documents and settings\blalba\desktop
[/quote]System.getProperty(“user.dir”) + “/desktop”;[/quote]
not quite, user.dir is the working directory, not the user home
you would want (iirc) user.home

also: that would work on some linux systems too, if they use ~/desktop/ for the desktop

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

supamagier:

just use C:\Documents and settings\blalba\desktop

Idiots… you are all idiots…

DO NOT use backslashes when typing directories, either use one forwardslash or File.pathSeparator to maintain the application platform-independant.

Yz told me to use backslashes a long time ago the first time i was saving files to a folder.
[/quote]Then he is an idiot.

Then again that was almost a year ago, so he might disagree if he see’s this thread.[/quote]Who the hell were you a year ago?

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:38, topic:213296”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=280774.msg2284808#msg2284808 date=1213863118]

Idiots… you are all idiots…

DO NOT use backslashes when typing directories, either use one forwardslash or File.pathSeparator to maintain the application platform-independant.

Yz told me to use backslashes a long time ago the first time i was saving files to a folder.

No, you were trying to tell me to use a backslash, actually. I said use a forward slash.

Ahh well, i really have no clue what wen’t on back then but i remember you helping me with my first batch IDE and you mentioned something about it.

You asked me about it, and I told you. I mentioned it because you were using a backwards slash, and I told you to use a forward slash.
[/quote]
Actually i remember, i was using one backslash and it said it didn’t read because theres commands or something (Forgot what they were called) that used \ in front of them, i think they were called escape characters. But yea, you told me double backslash, but oh well, i barely remember also.[/quote]
… Uh, no. You asked me “why isn’t this working, I have \ and it’s not compiling?” and I said you need to escape it with another backslash.

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:7, topic:213296”]thats why you need to catch the exception. Also when writing directory paths use a double \.

[code]
try {

} catch (IOException e) {
//What to do if it is not found.
}
[/code][/quote]
You’re a moron, use a forward slash or File.pathSeparator.

[quote=“Frell, post:22, topic:213296”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=280774.msg2282716#msg2282716 date=1213764352]
Idiots… you are all idiots…

DO NOT use backslashes when typing directories, either use one forwardslash or File.pathSeparator to maintain the application platform-independant.
[/quote]
Yz told me to use backslashes a long time ago the first time i was saving files to a folder.[/quote]
No, you were trying to tell me to use a backslash, actually. I said use a forward slash.

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

some OSes doesnt even have a desktop,
but Ollie’s code works for windows, and my linux machine,
probably will work for mac,

its good enough

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:28, topic:213296”]try {
BufferedWriter out = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(System.getProperty(“user.home”) + “Desktop” +
System.getProperty(“file.separator”) + “file.extension”));
out.write(“contents”);
out.flush();
out.close();
} catch (IOException e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}[/quote]So every OS has their Desktop folder set in the user.home directory?

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

How mature one can be… We were just trying to help, if not you, perhaps someone else who reads this thread and have the same kind of problem.

Also, the first alternative posted is, in my opinion, not a very good solution. What Ollie posted, using java.lang.System.getProperty(…), would be the better way to get your desktop-path.

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @rscheater13 rscheater13
item.description:
@rscheater13 wrote:

The problem was solved so I don’t know why you “IDIOTS” are still posting how to do it.

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

And also, the Notepad is somewhat strange (compared to other document-programs), but if I remember it correctly, you can just use the “\r\n” (carriage-return + line-feed) instead of “\n” (line-feed) to write a new line without what you called “[]” (boxes).

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Files To Desktop
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

try {
BufferedWriter out = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(System.getProperty(“user.home”) + “Desktop” +
System.getProperty(“file.separator”) + “file.extension”));
out.write(“contents”);
out.flush();
out.close();
} catch (IOException e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}

Read full topic
